segment.source: This article explains how to load and save image files using BitmapDecoder and BitmapEncoder and how to use the SoftwareBitmap object to represent bitmap images.
segment.target: This article explains how to load and save image files using BitmapDecoder and BitmapEncoder and how to use the SoftwareBitmap object to represent bitmap images.

segment.source: Imaging
segment.target: Imaging

segment.source: Imaging
segment.target: Imaging

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: This article explains how to load and save image files using BitmapDecoder and BitmapEncoder and how to use the SoftwareBitmap object to represent bitmap images.
segment.target: This article explains how to load and save image files using BitmapDecoder and BitmapEncoder and how to use the SoftwareBitmap object to represent bitmap images.

segment.source: The SoftwareBitmap class is a versatile API that can be created from multiple sources including image files, WriteableBitmap objects, Direct3D surfaces, and code.
segment.target: The SoftwareBitmap class is a versatile API that can be created from multiple sources including image files, WriteableBitmap objects, Direct3D surfaces, and code.

segment.source: SoftwareBitmap allows you to easily convert between different pixel formats and alpha modes, and allows low-level access to pixel data.
segment.target: SoftwareBitmap allows you to easily convert between different pixel formats and alpha modes, and allows low-level access to pixel data.

segment.source: Also, SoftwareBitmap is a common interface used by multiple features of Windows, including:
segment.target: Also, SoftwareBitmap is a common interface used by multiple features of Windows, including:

segment.source: CapturedFrame allows you to get frames captured by the camera as a SoftwareBitmap.
segment.target: CapturedFrame allows you to get frames captured by the camera as a SoftwareBitmap.

segment.source: VideoFrame allows you to get a SoftwareBitmap representation of a VideoFrame.
segment.target: VideoFrame allows you to get a SoftwareBitmap representation of a VideoFrame.

segment.source: FaceDetector allows you to detect faces in a SoftwareBitmap.
segment.target: FaceDetector allows you to detect faces in a SoftwareBitmap.

segment.source: The sample code in this article uses APIs from the following namespaces.
segment.target: The sample code in this article uses APIs from the following namespaces.

segment.source: Namespaces
segment.target: Namespaces

segment.source: Create a SoftwareBitmap from an image file with BitmapDecoder
segment.target: Create a SoftwareBitmap from an image file with BitmapDecoder

segment.source: To create a SoftwareBitmap from a file, get an instance of StorageFile containing the image data.
segment.target: To create a SoftwareBitmap from a file, get an instance of StorageFile containing the image data.

segment.source: This example uses a FileOpenPicker to allow the user to select an image file.
segment.target: This example uses a FileOpenPicker to allow the user to select an image file.

segment.source: PickInputFile
segment.target: PickInputFile

segment.source: Call the OpenAsync method of the StorageFile object to get a random access stream containing the image data.
segment.target: Call the OpenAsync method of the StorageFile object to get a random access stream containing the image data.

segment.source: Call the static method BitmapDecoder.CreateAsync to get an instance of the BitmapDecoder class for the specified stream.
segment.target: Call the static method BitmapDecoder.CreateAsync to get an instance of the BitmapDecoder class for the specified stream.

segment.source: Call GetSoftwareBitmapAsync to get a SoftwareBitmap object containing the image.
segment.target: Call GetSoftwareBitmapAsync to get a SoftwareBitmap object containing the image.

segment.source: CreateSoftwareBitmapFromFile
segment.target: CreateSoftwareBitmapFromFile

segment.source: Save a SoftwareBitmap to a file with BitmapEncoder
segment.target: Save a SoftwareBitmap to a file with BitmapEncoder

segment.source: To save a SoftwareBitmap to a file, get an instance of StorageFile to which the image will be saved.
segment.target: To save a SoftwareBitmap to a file, get an instance of StorageFile to which the image will be saved.

segment.source: This example uses a FileSavePicker to allow the user to select an output file.
segment.target: This example uses a FileSavePicker to allow the user to select an output file.

segment.source: PickOuputFile
segment.target: PickOuputFile

segment.source: Call the OpenAsync method of the StorageFile object to get a random access stream to which the image will be written.
segment.target: Call the OpenAsync method of the StorageFile object to get a random access stream to which the image will be written.

segment.source: Call the static method BitmapEncoder.CreateAsync to get an instance of the BitmapEncoder class for the specified stream.
segment.target: Call the static method BitmapEncoder.CreateAsync to get an instance of the BitmapEncoder class for the specified stream.

segment.source: The first parameter to CreateAsync is a GUID representing the codec that should be used to encode the image.
segment.target: The first parameter to CreateAsync is a GUID representing the codec that should be used to encode the image.

segment.source: BitmapEncoder class exposes a property containing the ID for each codec supported by the encoder, such as JpegEncoderId.
segment.target: BitmapEncoder class exposes a property containing the ID for each codec supported by the encoder, such as JpegEncoderId.

segment.source: Use the SetSoftwareBitmap method to set the image that will be encoded.
segment.target: Use the SetSoftwareBitmap method to set the image that will be encoded.

segment.source: You can set values of the BitmapTransform property to apply basic transforms to the image while it is being encoded.
segment.target: You can set values of the BitmapTransform property to apply basic transforms to the image while it is being encoded.

segment.source: The IsThumbnailGenerated property determines whether a thumbnail is generated by the encoder.
segment.target: The IsThumbnailGenerated property determines whether a thumbnail is generated by the encoder.

segment.source: Note that not all file formats support thumbnails, so if you use this feature, you should catch the unsupported operation error that will be thrown if thumbnails are not supported.
segment.target: Note that not all file formats support thumbnails, so if you use this feature, you should catch the unsupported operation error that will be thrown if thumbnails are not supported.

segment.source: Call FlushAsync to cause the encoder to write the image data to the specified file.
segment.target: Call FlushAsync to cause the encoder to write the image data to the specified file.

segment.source: SaveSoftwareBitmapToFile
segment.target: SaveSoftwareBitmapToFile

segment.source: You can specify additional encoding options when you create the BitmapEncoder by creating a new BitmapPropertySet object and populating it with one or more BitmapTypedValue objects representing the encoder settings.
segment.target: You can specify additional encoding options when you create the BitmapEncoder by creating a new BitmapPropertySet object and populating it with one or more BitmapTypedValue objects representing the encoder settings.

segment.source: For a list of supported encoder options, see BitmapEncoder options reference.
segment.target: For a list of supported encoder options, see BitmapEncoder options reference.

segment.source: UseEncodingOptions
segment.target: UseEncodingOptions

segment.source: Use SoftwareBitmap with a XAML Image control
segment.target: Use SoftwareBitmap with a XAML Image control

segment.source: To display an image within a XAML page using the Image control, first define an Image control in your XAML page.
segment.target: To display an image within a XAML page using the Image control, first define an Image control in your XAML page.

segment.source: ImageControl
segment.target: ImageControl

segment.source: Currently, the Image control only supports images that use BGRA8 encoding and pre-multiplied or no alpha channel.
segment.target: Currently, the Image control only supports images that use BGRA8 encoding and pre-multiplied or no alpha channel.

segment.source: Before attempting to display an image, test to make sure it has the correct format, and if not, use the SoftwareBitmap static Convert method to convert the image to the supported format.
segment.target: Before attempting to display an image, test to make sure it has the correct format, and if not, use the SoftwareBitmap static Convert method to convert the image to the supported format.

segment.source: Create a new SoftwareBitmapSource object.
segment.target: Create a new SoftwareBitmapSource object.

segment.source: Set the contents of the source object by calling SetBitmapAsync, passing in a SoftwareBitmap.
segment.target: Set the contents of the source object by calling SetBitmapAsync, passing in a SoftwareBitmap.

segment.source: Then you can set the Source property of the Image control to the newly created SoftwareBitmapSource.
segment.target: Then you can set the Source property of the Image control to the newly created SoftwareBitmapSource.

segment.source: SoftwareBitmapToWriteableBitmap
segment.target: SoftwareBitmapToWriteableBitmap

segment.source: You can also use SoftwareBitmapSource to set a SoftwareBitmap as the ImageSource for an ImageBrush.
segment.target: You can also use SoftwareBitmapSource to set a SoftwareBitmap as the ImageSource for an ImageBrush.

segment.source: Create a SoftwareBitmap from a WriteableBitmap
segment.target: Create a SoftwareBitmap from a WriteableBitmap

segment.source: You can create a SoftwareBitmap from an existing WriteableBitmap by calling SoftwareBitmap.CreateCopyFromBuffer and supplying the PixelBuffer property of the WriteableBitmap to set the pixel data.
segment.target: You can create a SoftwareBitmap from an existing WriteableBitmap by calling SoftwareBitmap.CreateCopyFromBuffer and supplying the PixelBuffer property of the WriteableBitmap to set the pixel data.

segment.source: The second argument allows you to request a pixel format for the newly created WriteableBitmap.
segment.target: The second argument allows you to request a pixel format for the newly created WriteableBitmap.

segment.source: You can use the PixelWidth and PixelHeight properties of the WriteableBitmap to specify the dimensions of the new image.
segment.target: You can use the PixelWidth and PixelHeight properties of the WriteableBitmap to specify the dimensions of the new image.

segment.source: WriteableBitmapToSoftwareBitmap
segment.target: WriteableBitmapToSoftwareBitmap

segment.source: Create or edit a SoftwareBitmap programmatically
segment.target: Create or edit a SoftwareBitmap programmatically

segment.source: So far this topic has addressed working with image files.
segment.target: So far this topic has addressed working with image files.

segment.source: You can also create a new SoftwareBitmap programatically in code and use the same technique to access and modify the SoftwareBitmap's pixel data.
segment.target: You can also create a new SoftwareBitmap programatically in code and use the same technique to access and modify the SoftwareBitmap's pixel data.

segment.source: SoftwareBitmap uses COM interop to expose the raw buffer containing the pixel data.
segment.target: SoftwareBitmap uses COM interop to expose the raw buffer containing the pixel data.

segment.source: To use COM interop, you must include a reference to the System.Runtime.InteropServices namespace in your project.
segment.target: To use COM interop, you must include a reference to the System.Runtime.InteropServices namespace in your project.

segment.source: InteropNamespace
segment.target: InteropNamespace

segment.source: Initialize the IMemoryBufferByteAccess COM interface by adding the following code within your namespace.
segment.target: Initialize the IMemoryBufferByteAccess COM interface by adding the following code within your namespace.

segment.source: COMImport
segment.target: COMImport

segment.source: Create a new SoftwareBitmap with pixel format and size you want.
segment.target: Create a new SoftwareBitmap with pixel format and size you want.

segment.source: Or, use an existing SoftwareBitmap for which you want to edit the pixel data.
segment.target: Or, use an existing SoftwareBitmap for which you want to edit the pixel data.

segment.source: Call SoftwareBitmap.LockBuffer to obtain an instance of the BitmapBuffer class representing the pixel data buffer.
segment.target: Call SoftwareBitmap.LockBuffer to obtain an instance of the BitmapBuffer class representing the pixel data buffer.

segment.source: Cast the BitmapBuffer to the IMemoryBufferByteAccess COM interface and then call IMemoryBufferByteAccess.GetBuffer to populate a byte array with data.
segment.target: Cast the BitmapBuffer to the IMemoryBufferByteAccess COM interface and then call IMemoryBufferByteAccess.GetBuffer to populate a byte array with data.

segment.source: Use the BitmapBuffer.GetPlaneDescription method to get a BitmapPlaneDescription object that will help you calculate the offset into the buffer for each pixel.
segment.target: Use the BitmapBuffer.GetPlaneDescription method to get a BitmapPlaneDescription object that will help you calculate the offset into the buffer for each pixel.

segment.source: CreateNewSoftwareBitmap
segment.target: CreateNewSoftwareBitmap

segment.source: Because this method accesses the raw buffer underlying the Windows Runtime types, it must be declared using the unsafe keyword.
segment.target: Because this method accesses the raw buffer underlying the Windows Runtime types, it must be declared using the unsafe keyword.

segment.source: You must also configure your project in Microsoft Visual Studio to allow the compilation of unsafe code by opening the project's Properties page, clicking the Build property page, and selecting the Allow Unsafe Code checkbox.
segment.target: You must also configure your project in Microsoft Visual Studio to allow the compilation of unsafe code by opening the project's Properties page, clicking the Build property page, and selecting the Allow Unsafe Code checkbox.

segment.source: Create a SoftwareBitmap from a Direct3D surface
segment.target: Create a SoftwareBitmap from a Direct3D surface

segment.source: To create a SoftwareBitmap object from a Direct3D surface, you must include the Windows.Graphics.DirectX.Direct3D11 namespace in your project.
segment.target: To create a SoftwareBitmap object from a Direct3D surface, you must include the Windows.Graphics.DirectX.Direct3D11 namespace in your project.

segment.source: Direct3DNamespace
segment.target: Direct3DNamespace

segment.source: Call CreateCopyFromSurfaceAsync to create a new SoftwareBitmap from the surface.
segment.target: Call CreateCopyFromSurfaceAsync to create a new SoftwareBitmap from the surface.

segment.source: As the name indicates, the new SoftwareBitmap has a separate copy of the image data.
segment.target: As the name indicates, the new SoftwareBitmap has a separate copy of the image data.

segment.source: Modifications to the SoftwareBitmap will not have any effect on the Direct3D surface.
segment.target: Modifications to the SoftwareBitmap will not have any effect on the Direct3D surface.

segment.source: CreateSoftwareBitmapFromSurface
segment.target: CreateSoftwareBitmapFromSurface

segment.source: Convert a SoftwareBitmap to a different pixel format
segment.target: Convert a SoftwareBitmap to a different pixel format

segment.source: The SoftwareBitmap class provides the static method, Convert, that allows you to easily create a new SoftwareBitmap that uses the pixel format and alpha mode you specify from an existing SoftwareBitmap.
segment.target: The SoftwareBitmap class provides the static method, Convert, that allows you to easily create a new SoftwareBitmap that uses the pixel format and alpha mode you specify from an existing SoftwareBitmap.

segment.source: Note that the newly created bitmap has a separate copy of the image data.
segment.target: Note that the newly created bitmap has a separate copy of the image data.

segment.source: Modifications to the new bitmap will not affect the source bitmap.
segment.target: Modifications to the new bitmap will not affect the source bitmap.

segment.source: Convert
segment.target: Convert

segment.source: Transcode an image file
segment.target: Transcode an image file

segment.source: You can transcode an image file directly from a BitmapDecoder to a BitmapEncoder.
segment.target: You can transcode an image file directly from a BitmapDecoder to a BitmapEncoder.

segment.source: Create a IRandomAccessStream from the file to be transcoded.
segment.target: Create a IRandomAccessStream from the file to be transcoded.

segment.source: Create a new BitmapDecoder from the input stream.
segment.target: Create a new BitmapDecoder from the input stream.

segment.source: Create a new InMemoryRandomAccessStream for the encoder to write to and call BitmapEncoder.CreateForTranscodingAsync, passing in the in-memory stream and the decoder object.
segment.target: Create a new InMemoryRandomAccessStream for the encoder to write to and call BitmapEncoder.CreateForTranscodingAsync, passing in the in-memory stream and the decoder object.

segment.source: Set the encoding properties you want.
segment.target: Set the encoding properties you want.

segment.source: Any properties in the input image file that you do not specifically set on the encoder, will be written to the output file unchanged.
segment.target: Any properties in the input image file that you do not specifically set on the encoder, will be written to the output file unchanged.

segment.source: Call FlushAsync to cause the encoder to encode to the in-memory stream.
segment.target: Call FlushAsync to cause the encoder to encode to the in-memory stream.

segment.source: Finally, seek the file stream and the in-memory stream to the beginning and call CopyAsync to write the in-memory stream out to the file stream.
segment.target: Finally, seek the file stream and the in-memory stream to the beginning and call CopyAsync to write the in-memory stream out to the file stream.

segment.source: TranscodeImageFile
segment.target: TranscodeImageFile
